Package com.cafean.jobstream.common.util

Class FileUtils

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.cafean.jobstream.common.util.FileUtils
  • public abstract class FileUtils
extends java.lang.Object
    A collection of file related utility methods.

      • getExtension

        public static java.lang.String getExtension​(java.io.File f)
        Returns the extension for the given file. This method assumes that an extension may only exist on non-directories whose extensions are preceeded by a period and at least one other character. Thus, passing a file with the name "sample.txt will return "txt" but a file named ".sample" would return null.
        Parameters:
        f - the file to check
        Returns:
        the extension, sans period, if the above conditions are met; null otherwise

      • removeExtension

        public static java.lang.String removeExtension​(java.io.File f)
        Returns the name of the given file, sans extension. This method assumes extension may only exist on non-directories whose extensions are preceeded by a period and at least one other character. Thus, passing a file with the name "sample.txt will return "sample" while a file named ".sample" would return ".sample".
        Parameters:
        f - the file to check
        Returns:
        the file name, sans extension, if the above conditions are met; null otherwise

      • removeExtension

        public static java.lang.String removeExtension​(java.lang.String name)
        Returns the name of the given file, sans extension. This method assumes extensions are preceeded by a period and at least one other character. Thus, passing a file with the name "sample.txt will return "sample" while a file named ".sample" would return ".sample".
        Parameters:
        name - the String to process
        Returns:
        the file name, sans extension, if the above conditions are met; null otherwise

      • getRelativePath

        public static java.lang.String getRelativePath​(java.io.File file,
                                               java.io.File anchor)
        Returns a String containing the path of the given file relative to the given anchor folder location.
        Parameters:
        file - the File for which to find the relative path
        anchor - a File referring to the folder to anchor the relative path to
        Returns:
        a String containing the relative path or null if the path cannot be resolved to a relative path

      • getRelativePath

        public static java.lang.String getRelativePath​(java.io.File file,
                                               java.io.File anchor,
                                               boolean useCanonical)
        Returns a String containing the path of the given file relative to the given anchor folder location.

        Passing false for the useCanonical parameter will prevent symbolic links, etc. from being resolved out of the path before comparison. This can be useful in situations where it's possible that symbolic links were used to shorten the resulting relative path.

        Parameters:
        file - the File for which to find the relative path
        anchor - a File referring to the folder to anchor the relative path to
        useCanonical - if true the canonical paths of the two arguments will be used; if false the absolute paths will be used instead.
        Returns:
        a String containing the relative path or null if the path cannot be resolved to a relative path

      • getFileByRelativePath

        public static java.io.File getFileByRelativePath​(java.io.File base,
                                                 java.lang.String... relativePath)
        Returns a File referring to the file or folder with the given relative (i.e. sub-folder) location under the given base location. The relative location must be separated by the forward slash ('/') separator character regardless of the current platform.

        For example: A base folder of C:\Program Files\ and a relative path of SNAP/lib/ would return C:\Program Files\SNAP\lib\.

        Parameters:
        base - a File referring to the base folder location at which to anchor the given relative path.
        relativePath - a String[] containing relative paths separated by the '/' separator character.
        Returns:
        a File referring to the relative location

      • appendPath

        public static java.lang.String appendPath​(java.lang.String basePath,
                                          java.lang.String... relativePaths)
        Returns a String containing the concatenation of the given paths with the base path.
        Parameters:
        basePath -
        relativePaths -
        Returns:

      • appendPath

        public static java.nio.file.Path appendPath​(java.nio.file.Path basePath,
                                            java.lang.String... relativePaths)
        Returns a the resolution of the given relative paths delimited with forward slashes (/) against the base path. This allows relative paths such as "project" and "xser/project" to be resolved against a base path of "c:\foo\" resulting in "c:\foo\xser\project\".
        Parameters:
        basePath - the Path used as the base to resolve relatives against
        relativePaths - the relative paths to resolve against the base
        Returns:
        the Path result of resolving each relative path against the base in the order they are given.

      • getFolderByRelativePath

        public static java.lang.String getFolderByRelativePath​(Architecture arch,
                                                       java.lang.String base,
                                                       java.lang.String... relativePath)
        Returns a String containing the path to the folder with the given relative (i.e. sub-folder) location under the given base location. The resulting path will be constructed using the separator character appropriate for the given architecture: backslash ('\') for windows and forward slash('/') for other systems.

        The relative location must be separated by the forward slash ('/') separator character regardless of the current platform.

        For example: A base folder of C:\Program Files\ and a relative path of SNAP/lib/ would return C:\Program Files\SNAP\lib\.

        Parameters:
        base - a File referring to the base folder location at which to anchor the given relative path.
        relativePath - a String containing a relative path separated by the '/' separator character.
        arch - the Architecture of the target platform
        Returns:
        a String containing the resulting folder path ending with an appropriate separator character based on the given architecture.

      • getParentPath

        public static java.lang.String getParentPath​(java.lang.String path)
        Returns the parent of the given path by removing the last path entry. Path entries are assumed to be separated by forward slash(/) characters.
        Returns:
        a String containing the path to the parent of the given path or null if no parent is possible (i.e. no separator character(/)).

      • getFolderName

        public static java.lang.String getFolderName​(java.lang.String path)
        Returns the name of the folder given by the (possibly relative) path separated by forward slash(/) characters.
        Returns:
        a String containing the name of the given path or null if it has no name (i.e. "/")

      • isSameFile

        public static boolean isSameFile​(java.io.File f1,
                                 java.io.File f2)
        Returns true if the two files are the same file by checking File.getCanonicalFile() and File.equals(java.lang.Object).

        Returns:

      • canWrite

        public static boolean canWrite​(java.io.File file)
        Returns true if the file can be written per File.canWrite() and a RandomAccessFile can be opened with read/write permissions. Note that the latter is only performed on windows as the return from File.canWrite() can be trusted on all other platforms.
        Parameters:
        file - the File to check write access for
        Returns:
        true if the file can be written
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the given file is a directory

      • canRead

        public static boolean canRead​(java.io.File file)
        Returns true if the file can be read per File.canRead() and a RandomAccessFile can be opened with read permissions. Note that the latter is only performed on windows as the return from File.canRead() can be trusted on all other platforms.
        Parameters:
        file - the File to check read access for
        Returns:
        true if the file can be read
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the given file is a directory

      • readCustomPropertiesFile

        public static java.util.Properties readCustomPropertiesFile()
                                                     throws java.io.IOException
        Retrieves and reads the custom installation properties from the file:

        [SNAP Install]/bin/snap.prop

        This is a standard Java properties file.

        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

                                                         java.lang.String filePath)
                                                  throws java.io.IOException
        Extracts the text contents of the source file named in the ZIP path from the given ZIP file and returns it as a string.
        Parameters:

        filePath - a String containing the path to the file to extract

      • extractFiles

        public static void extractFiles​(java.io.File zipFile,
                                java.io.File targetDirectory,
                                java.lang.String prefix)
                         throws java.io.IOException
        Extract every entry in the ZIP file that starts with the prefix to the target directory.
        Parameters:
        zipFile - a File reference to the ZIP file to extract
        targetDirectory - a File reference to the target directory
        prefix - a String containing the prefix to match with zip entries
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • zipFile

        public static boolean zipFile​(java.lang.String entryPath,
                              java.io.File localFile,
                              java.util.zip.ZipOutputStream zipOutput)
        This utility method adds a File object to a ZipOutputStream
        Parameters:
        entryPath - the relative path for the file inside the zip.
        localFile - the File that should be copied into the zip file.
        zipOutput - the ZipOutputStream that is being zipped.
        Returns:
        true unless an IOException has been thrown.

      • zipFile

        public static boolean zipFile​(java.lang.String entryPath,
                              java.lang.String fileName,
                              java.io.File localFile,
                              java.util.zip.ZipOutputStream zipOutput)
        This utility method adds a File object to a ZipOutputStream
        Parameters:
        entryPath - the relative path for the file inside the zip.
        fileName - the name of the file inside the zip file. This allows for renaming files as they are added to the zip file.
        localFile - the File that should be copied into the zip file.
        zipOutput - the ZipOutputStream that is being zipped.
        Returns:
        TRUE unless an IOException has been thrown.

      • getManifestProperty

        public static java.lang.String getManifestProperty​(java.lang.Class aClass,
                                                   java.lang.String property)
                                            throws java.io.IOException
        Attempts to load the requested property from the manifest of the JAR file that contains the given class.
        Parameters:
        aClass - a Class reference to some class included in the JAR file.
        property - a String containing the name of the property to retrieve
        Returns:
        a String containing the value of the property or null if none is found.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - when encountering errors while reading the JAR
